properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 20 to 40 cm is expected. Locations: Upper Lake Melville, Eagle River, and Rigolet and vicinity. Time span: later this morning until Saturday evening. Remarks: Northeasterly to northwesterly winds gusting to 60 or 70 km/h will combine with the fresh snowfall to give blowing snow at times tonight and Saturday, especially over exposed areas. ### Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-03-27T23:59:12-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-27T08:00:12-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2411645059.2020
Area: Rigolet and vicinity, Upper Lake Melville, Eagle River
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Heavy snow will begin Friday afternoon. Snowfall accumulations will reach 30 cm by Saturday afternoon. In addition, an Arctic front will push through Pine Pass Friday night producing northeast winds of 30 to 40 km/h with gusts to 60. The winds and snow will reduce visibility in blowing snow. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-27T14:50:54-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-26T22:51:54-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3746428918.2020
Area: Highway 97 - Pine Pass
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow and rain expected tonight, Friday, and Friday night. Total snowfall: 5 to 10 cm. Total rainfall: 10 to 20 mm. Strongest winds: southeasterly 80 km/h on Friday, followed by southwesterlies 60 km/h Friday night. Location: western and southwestern Newfoundland, as well as northeastern and parts of central. Time span: tonight until overnight Friday night. Remarks: Snow in the south will spread elsewhere through the night. Precipitation will change over to rain by Friday afternoon or evening. The rain will be accompanied by temperatures several degrees above freezing, resulting in snow melt and pooling water. The rain is expected to taper to isolated flurries Friday night, except in the west where rain will change back to snow Friday evening and continue through the night. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-03-27T17:09:57-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-27T01:10:57-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1902308673.2020

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow and blowing snow is expected Friday night and Saturday. Maximum snowfall: 10 cm with locally higher amounts possible. Strongest winds: northerly near 80 km/h. Time span: Friday evening to Saturday evening. Remarks: Snow will begin Friday afternoon and taper off Saturday evening. Strong northerly winds will develop Friday night and will persist on Saturday. These winds will combine with fresh snow to cause reduced visibilities in blowing snow. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-03-27T17:16:14-00:00

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of freezing rain is expected this evening before precipitation changes over to snow. Local ice accretion of 2 millimetres is possible. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-27T08:59:45-00:00

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. Total snowfall: 15 to 40 cm. Freezing rain: 5 to 10 mm possible. Maximum wind gusts: northeasterly up to 60 km/h. Les Suetes winds up to 90 km/h. Locations: eastern Nova Scotia, including Cape Breton. Time span: until Friday morning except into the afternoon for the Cape Breton Highlands. Remarks: Snow will transition to a mix of ice pellets or freezing rain overnight. Freezing rain is expected to change over or mix with rain mainly over eastern Cape Breton before switching back to flurries Friday afternoon. Over the Cape Breton Highlands, a switch over to snow and blowing snow with reduced visibility is expected on Friday. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-27T17:31:14-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-27T01:32:14-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2884988806.2020
Area: Guysborough County, Antigonish County, Richmond County, Inverness County - south of Mabou, Inverness County - Mabou and north, Victoria County, Sydney Metro and Cape Breton County
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Heavy snowfall with blowing snow is expected. Total snowfall: near 15 cm. Maximum wind gusts: northeasterly near 70 km/h. Location: the Labrador Straits. Time span: early this morning until early this evening. Remarks: Snow, at times heavy, will combine with strong northeasterly winds causing blowing snow through the day today. The snow will change through ice pellets and freezing rain to to rain this evening. Rainfall amounts of near 10 mm are forecast for tonight. ### Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Wreckhouse Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Maximum gusts: easterly 120 km/h. Time span: continuing until later this morning. ### Wreckhouse wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A snowstorm is expected. Total snowfall: 15 to 25 cm. Maximum wind gusts: easterly near 80 km/h. Location: the eastern half of the Great Northern Peninsula. Time span: continuing until this evening. Remarks: Snow at times heavy and strong easterly winds will combine to reduce visibility in blowing snow today. Conditions will improve this evening as the snow transitions to rain. ### Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls are expected to develop. Under the snow squall bands, visibilities will be significantly reduced due to the heavy snow, and snow will quickly accumulate. Total snowfall: possibility of 15 to 25 cm in snow squalls. Maximum wind gusts: 70 km/h. Locations: western Cape Breton. Time span: this evening and overnight. Remarks: Flurries will become heavy at times this evening, with risk of snow squall activity as cold northwesterly winds strengthen. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snow squall watches are issued when conditions are favourable for the formation of bands of snow that could produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-27T23:49:16-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-27T07:50:16-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3527416252.2020
Area: Inverness County - Mabou and north
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with poor visibility in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. A storm system approaching from the south will bring blizzard conditions to Resolute beginning early this morning. These blizzard conditions will be accompanied with very strong easterly winds of 70 gusting 90 km/h. Conditions will improve near midnight tonight as the wind begins to weaken. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 6 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-28T00:37:39-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-27T08:38:39-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3568842991.2020
Area: Resolute
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with gusty winds and visibility frequently near zero in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. Total snowfall: 20 to 30 cm. Maximum wind gusts: northerly 80 km/h. Locations: Makkovik to Hopedale and vicinity. Time span: Friday afternoon until Saturday evening. Remarks: Snow, at times heavy, is expected to develop Friday afternoon and taper off Saturday evening. Strong northerly winds will develop Friday evening and persist through Saturday. Conditions will improve by Saturday evening. ### Travel is expected to be extremely hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 4 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-03-27T17:12:54-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-27T01:13:54-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2071634338.2020

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. Very strong easterly winds will develop in Grise Fiord today. The wind will begin to strengthen this morning, with gusts up to 100 km/h expected later today. With these gusty winds, periods of blowing snow are also expected. These very strong winds will begin to weaken this evening and become light Saturday morning. ### Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-28T00:42:38-00:00

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. Maximum wind gusts: southeasterly near 100 km/h. Locations: the Avalon and Bonavista peninsulas. Time span: continuing until this evening. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. Between 15 and 20 centimetres of snow as well as blowing snow are expected over these regions. Snow at times heavy along with northeast winds of up to 90 kilometres per hour will affect the Lower North Shore beginning early Friday morning. Quickly accumulating snow and reduced visibilities could make travel difficult. A period of rain is possible in Blanc-Sablon Friday evening. Conditions should improve early Saturday morning. ### Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-27T11:25:55-00:00

Area: Chevery, Blanc-Sablon
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, heavy at times is expected. The frozen ground has a reduced ability to absorb this rainfall. Total rainfall: up to 25 mm. Locations: the south coast and east coast of Newfoundland. Time span: continuing until this evening. Remarks: Snow will change to rain at times heavy this morning. The rain will be accompanied by mild temperatures and strong easterly winds, resulting in significant snow melt. As a result, localized flooding is likely. ### Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-03-27T23:34:55-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-27T07:35:55-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1065206710.2020

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, heavy at times is expected. The frozen ground has a reduced ability to absorb this rainfall. Total rainfall: 15 to 25 mm, except as high as 40 mm for the Burin and Connaigre peninsulas. Locations: the Avalon, Burin, Connaigre, and Bonavista peninsulas, as well as Clarenville and Terra Nova. Time span: overnight tonight until Friday evening. Remarks: Snow will develop tonight before changing to rain by Friday morning. The rain will be accompanied by mild temperatures and strong easterly winds, resulting in significant snow melt. As a result, localized flooding is likely. The public is therefore advised to clear storm drains of ice and snow where possible ahead of the rain. ### Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-03-27T16:54:54-00:00

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Brief, intense snowfall is expected to develop. Under the snow squall, visibilities will be significantly reduced due to the heavy snow combined with blowing snow. Visibility in snow and blowing snow will be significantly reduced Friday afternoon and evening as an Arctic front blasts through the region. The sudden onset of snow with strong winds will create visibilities near zero in blowing snow for a brief period of time as the front passes. Visibilities will improve late Friday in the wake of the front. ### Travel may be hazardous due to sudden changes in the weather. Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Snow squall watches are issued when conditions are favourable for the formation of bands of snow that could produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-27T14:50:35-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-26T22:51:35-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0604404492.2020
Area: B.C. South Peace River, B.C. North Peace River
properties.Author: Environment Canada
